I am honored to tell Cory‚Äôs story and join Nebraskans and Americans across our county in saluting Cory‚Äôs willingness to serve.

Today, if you go to Chadron, Nebraska you will see the Sergeant Cory Mracek Memorial Post Office. I was proud to work w/ former NE Senator Mike Johanns on a bill renaming this post office in honor Cory.
Communities came together to line the streets as his funeral procession went through their town as it made its 46-mile journey across Nebraska.
A week later 600 family members, friends, and military officials gathered inside a Nebraska gymnasium to celebrate and honor Cory and his sacrifice for our country.
Cory and two other U.S. service members were killed by the explosion. #NEhero

On January 27, 2004, his mother remembers spending the morning instant messaging with Cory to catch up and see how he was doing. Later that same day, Cory and his reconnaissance platoon were performing a mission where they came across an IED.
After a couple of years in active duty, he was deployed to #Iraq to an area that saw major combat activity and sectarian violence during 2003-2007.

He came back home in 2001 and transitioned back to the @NENationalGuard. However, when 9/11 happened, Cory told his parents that he was going to go back to the Active Army so he could serve his country. #Service

A year later, Cory transferred to the Active Army & was soon deployed to South Korea. He enjoyed his time there and he even participated in the #ManchuaMile where he marched for 24-miles in full combat gear.
After graduating high school, he went on to attend college at @Chadronstate. While in college he decided to join the @NENationalGuard and left to go train at Fort Sill, Oklahoma. #NEhero
During high school, he became involved in many extracurricular activities and played basketball and football.
Born in Chadron, Nebraska, Cory Mracek was always trying to have a good time. He was often found either laughing or trying to make others laugh.

NOW: I‚Äôm continuing my tributes to the men and women who have lost their lives defending our freedom. Please join me in honoring Sergeant Cory Mracek of Hay Springs, NE.  https://www.senate.gov/floor/index.htm¬†

#Russia and #China are building up their nuclear forces; unilaterally cutting our deterrent ignores this reality. It is not the answer. More:  https://www.fischer.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/news?ID=0476BDD7-EF18-40F1-83B5-D863021F8A5B¬†‚Ä¶
Just last week, @US_Stratcom Commander General Hyten testified that our nuclear forces represent the bare minimum required to protect the United States.

Both the Obama and @realdonaldtrump administrations agree on the value of the triad, as has every administration since the Eisenhower-era. The testimony from our senior military leaders has also been clear and consistent: Our nuclear triad is necessary to keep our nation safe.

Today @HASCDemocrats Chair @RepAdamSmith said he doesn‚Äôt think ICBMs are necessary for nuclear deterrence. To casually assert that an entire leg of the triad is superfluous disregards the best advice of our military leadership. It is a dangerous, misguided assertion.
